segments.text: This is Deborah Beale interviewing Mr. Don Feltz on the history of the Texas Engineering Experiment Station.
The date is June 14, 1984.
Okay, that looks like that is working now.
Okay, now how you came to A&M?
Okay, your question was how did I get associated with A&M.
Okay, I was first a student here in 1951, and stayed here two years until I was drafted into the Army because of the Korean War, and then I did not get back to A&M until 1957.
I continued my studies toward a degree in mechanical engineering.
And then that was followed by my immediate entry into graduate school as a nuclear engineer.
At the time I graduated in mechanical engineering, the nuclear engineering department had actually not been founded.
We were taking nuclear engineering courses, but they were being offered through the Department of Mechanical Engineering.
And shortly thereafter,
I'd say in 1960 or so, they formed the Nuclear Engineering Department.
And that's when they brought Dr. Cochran here, not only to head up nuclear engineering, but also to be head of the Nuclear Science Center, which at that time was in its design phase.
The studies and proposals for funding from the National Science Foundation
the Department of Energy had all been completed and the design work started on the Science Center in 59.
About the time I was finishing up my undergraduate work in mechanical engineering.
So, shortly after I got into the nuclear engineering course work, I took an assistantship where I was assigned to the Nuclear Science Center
We were housed on campus in the old highway research building, which is across the street from the, uh, petroleum engineering, the, uh, Girardi building.
And we were, at that time, when I joined the science center, they'd already started excavation, all the construction.
So I continued, uh,
with my graduate studies, working as a half-time research assistant, or student assistant.
Proper term, I guess, is graduate assistant.
Get it right in a minute.
And I stayed in that capacity until 1963, when I completed my studies.
And then I became full-time employed at the Science Center as reactor supervisor.
And two years after that, the administration changed at the Science Center.
Dr. Cochran was put back, say, only in charge of the engineering department, and they brought a director to the Science Center, changed the title from head to director, and that was Dr. John Randall.
And I was named the assistant at that time, in 1965.
So I've had just about all the jobs that are available out here since that time.
And then later, I was named the associate director to the center.
When you first started studying nuclear science,
Were you pretty sure they were going to get the funding and everything to establish the center?
Oh, yes.
Yeah, we had the funding in hand when I started.
That work was done by, mainly by Dr. Dick Winerdi, Rich Winerdi, and Dr. Calhoun.
They were responsible for putting the package together, the proposals, to get the funding for the center.
There were several things at that time that the university wanted to get into for the advancement of engineering and science.
One was a data processing center.
One was a nuclear science center, which both became reality.
These were all in the era of Dr. Calhoun and Dean Benson and Dr. Wernherde.
At the time, Dr. Wernherde was
His responsibility was gathering the information for the proposals and getting something started in the nuclear engineering as far as the reactor was concerned, too.
Of course, we were placed from the very beginning under the Tees.
As far as Tees administration, I remember only Dean Benson.
The previous director, I did not know that well, but there was a little crossover there, I think, when I was one of the graduate assistants.
I think my first Form 500 was actually signed by Dr. Rose.
So, if I'm not making an error, I think Dean Benson must have taken the directorship of Tees about that time.
So I was pretty close there because I did start in 59.
So you have to obviously mention Dr. Rose as far as the development of the nuclear science center.
Because it actually started, it was a deputy under study while he was still director of the team.
Do you know who instigated the whole idea of the nuclear science center?
I would think it would be Dr. Calhoun from discussions with him since that time.
I think it was his idea to bring Dr. Wernherdi to Texas A&M with the specific assignment to put together the proposal to get the funding for this center.
Now there was a mini reactor or something before.
Yes, at the time.
I started my studies in nuclear engineering.
There was a small reactor placed in the mechanical engineering shops.
It was called an AGN 201 reactor, and Dr. Randall, who was not a doctor at the time, but John Randall, came to Texas A&M in perhaps 59, late 58, to put that reactor in.
It's a training reactor.
It's still here at Texas A&M.
It's located now in the basement of Zachary.
It's associated with the Department of Nuclear Engineering.
It's a very low-power reactor used in training, training for engineering students or reactor operators.
It does have some research capabilities, but they're quite limited because of the
what we consider the low power of the reactor.
It's the type of machine that if the operator makes an error, it shuts down very quickly.
He must maintain the instruments within full range of the capability of each instrument.
If he goes off scale, either on the high end or off the bottom end of the scale, he's going to lose the reactor.
It's going to shut down on him.
So he has to be very careful to make sure the instruments stay on the proper scales.
And there's one reason it's called training reactor.
You're spending a lot of time paying attention to the controls.
Now that was moved, by the way, when Zachary was built.
They moved the reactor from the shops into the Zachary Center, the engineering center.
It's now associated with the Department of Nuclear Engineering complex they have there.
It's on a different level than the classrooms.
There's a large laboratory associated above the reactor as well as you can work around the reactor itself.
It's quite large in size as far as the facility
compared to the space we had over in the ME shops.
We were just more or less placed in the corner of that large building and then a separate little building was built around it.
They were doing mostly biological radiation studies?
Not with that reactor, no.
That reactor was used mainly in the class instruction
lab work for nuclear engineering students.
When did TWU have Grant come to use it for bone research or something?
The 201?
I'm not familiar with that.
That must not have happened when I was there.
Maybe later.
When did they, I've seen pictures of the, all the rat research and the exposure of the rats.
Was that once the complex was created?
Well, the exposure of those animals, I can recall two ways they were done.
Dr. Sidney Brown and Dr. Christ of biology, radiation biology.
They had a Cobalt 60 facility on campus, a very small source that I remember as a graduate assistant, we had to sometimes go over and do maintenance to that facility.
And they had a few animals in cages there.
But that was in one of the old army-type buildings, barracks buildings, yeah.
Is that what you remember seeing?
Yeah, that's the type of building.
It didn't look like one of the new buildings.
Building F or something over by what was back behind the Indian Press at that time.
And they tore most of those buildings down.
I still see one over there.
Did they bring most of that research out here or something?

once we yes because we added to this center a special facility for the radiation of animals it's not part of the reactor building it's it's a separate building that was built on our site and it housed a very large cobalt 60 source and you could when you raise the source for exposure there was a large field with a dirt mound to catch the
radiation you're not using, the stray radiation.
And you could place small houses of animals out on the field.
And you can place them at varying distances from the source and irradiate them.
And we operated that source for many years.
No, the source has been dismantled.
The building is still there and the shield is still there.
When was it dismantled?
That's a good question.
Early 70s.
When was it first opened?
In, I'd say, 60... Well, okay, it opened very close to the time we opened.
I'd say 63, 64.
It was planned very early as part of the Science Center to have a nuclear reactor source, which is basically a neutron source, and then to have the separate gamma facility.
for life science studies.
The research that was done in cooperation with MD Anderson, was that done here or in Houston?
Well, we've done quite a bit of work for MD Anderson and still do.
Are you talking about the gold seeds?
I haven't been able to really understand exactly what kind, but I knew there was radiation research.
Oh yes, the MD Anderson Tumor Institute.
He's done a lot of research at A&M, both at this reactor facility and also the psychotropic.
We have not been involved with any where the patients come to us for any treatment, any radiation treatment.
What we're producing here are isotopes that are implanted in cancerous tumors.
We produce the
basic radioactive material they use, which is gold.
It's a little tiny gold seed about the diameter of a pencil lid, thin line pencil lid, roughly a tenth of an inch in length.
And it's platinum coated so that it can be made surgically clean.
And then we produce the radioactivity in the little seed.
And we produce the quantity of activity they desire
at a certain time on a certain day for implant in the patient.

And we have to make obviously more radioactivity than is needed because there's two or three days in between for handling of the material to get it shipped back down to Houston and get it through their laboratory because they will assay it for its strength to make sure that it's the proper strength at the time of surgery.
And we've been doing that for many years, still doing it.
Was that process developed here?
In the early stages of that experimental work, it wasn't indeed an experiment.
It was experimental all the way, and the patients, we were told, were terminal.
And of course, we never got involved with that end of it.
But now, this is standard therapy.
But that therapy was developed here?
Yes, as a result of the work we did.
Of course, now when we speak with Dr. Calhoun, maybe this is where you heard that story.
He was one of the founding fathers of this facility, and then what, 20 years later or whatever, 22, 20-so years later, he actually
benefited from the implants of the gold we make.
He's had these implants for treatment of cancer.
Do you plan to interview Dr. Kemp?
I plan to, yes.
Well, he's a must.
He's a must in your interview because he will tie together all these dates we're talking about on the Science Center and the involvement of Dr. Wernherg.
After Dr. Mornerdi's initial involvement in the proposal gathering, and the fund gathering rather, he then became a primary researcher here at the facility.
He developed the Activation Analysis Research Laboratory, called AARL as we knew it in those days.
That's been shut down.
Well, it's been transferred.
The function has and renamed.
It's now the center trace characterization.
It's part of that center.
But it's still neutron activation analysis.
There was a lot of activity there.
They were one of our mainstays in the early years here.
Their laboratory was part of our facility.
They occupied a very large facility.
space in the reactor, upper research level as we call it, where their equipment was very close to the reactor.
And we've since improved the method of delivering samples using high pressure gas.
We call them pneumatic systems.
And that lab was later removed from that area adjacent to the reactor.
And when we built this new lab addition right in here,
We sent the samples much longer distances.
And the Center for Trace Characterization still have a lab here, always have had.
That's an activity that we've never been without, either under the name of Activation Analysis Research Lab or CTC.
Do you know when that center started?
Oh, the AARL?
No, the Center for... Oh, that?
No.
It was set up to collect the activities of various groups, put them under one collection, one directionship, and that's now being done under the Department of Chemistry.
in the College of Science.
And Dr. Swiker is the director of that center.
Which were a very vital and essential facility to that research.
Because they have to have the reactor to get the neutrons to do that work.
Besides the activation analysis, what was going on at the
Well, in the early days, we were producing isotopes.
There's always been an interest in the Houston area.
First in just isotope production.
These would be basically commercial users.
The petrochemical companies have always shown interest in the reactor.
And then we have the isotope suppliers that are supplying the hospitals and industry in the Southwest on the commercial side.
We've been working with those users out of Houston.
But our main thrust in those days was working, of course, with the university, developing programs in the various departments, biochemistry, chemistry, life sciences, animal science.
Some of our early experimenters, for example, was Dr. Deeker, still with A&M.
Maybe a person you'd like to interview because I would say he was part of the history of this science center.
He was around when we started and one of our earlier experimenters.
He ran a project here for many years.
looking at the uptake of minerals in peanuts.
We would irradiate his peanut samples.
He would analyze those samples for the minerals that were present.
He was developing nutritional plant foods, I'd say, for the peanuts.
Also, he was trying to determine the processes
by which this plant was actually picking up the minerals.
It led to better fertilizers and also higher production yields in the plant cycle.
All this being traced using radioactive materials.
Again, it's what we call the neutron activation analysis.
Neutron activation analysis is a very important part of
of nuclear reactor research, the users of these facilities.
Even the small reactors, you can provide this service.
The little 201, for example, on campus, you could do a small amount of what we call the NAA on it, simply because neutrons are present.
Neutrons, when they enter a substance,
They interreact with the nuclei and in that process the radioactivity is produced.
Each element that's present becomes radioactive.
And then it's up to the scientist to have the technique and the skills to identify what he's made radioactive.
In doing so he can quantify what's in the sample.
That's really all we do.
As well as
If he runs standards of known weights, known masses, he can then compare the unknown sample to a known sample and then determine the quantity of the material that's present.
So it's a full analysis of the sample.
You can do this by chemistry as well, but there are some big advantages
in many cases by doing it with neutron, the neutron method rather than the chemical method.
Very good explanation.
Something I hadn't been able to figure out from the technical publications.
They assume you know what it is.
That's what it is.
And then the other work we got into in the early days was to work with our beam ports, which are penetrations through the reactor shield structure
They're much like large telescopes, the way they're fabricated there.

They start near the reactor with a small diameter pipe, and then as you work your way through the shield structure, these sections of pipes get larger, which allows you to place shielding material in the pipes and leave, say, a tiny hole through the center.
If you line the hole up all the way through the port,

you will get a beam of radiation coming down the hole and you can shape that beam have it large or you can have it very small you can place materials in the beam and if you don't want to look at what would be coming directly off the reactor you can do what we call secondary reactions allow the neutrons to interact with the target and then
you indeed then look at that target through the beam.
Let whatever the secondary reactions are come down the beam.
And in the 60s and the years prior to that, 40s, 50s, there was a lot of particle physics going on.
These studies were being conducted at research reactors.
Of course, the cyclotron or accelerators came into being.
That gave the scientists another tool to work with.
Again, you're involved with radioactivity when you work with a cyclotron or an accelerator.
It's a different machine entirely than a nuclear reactor.
The scientist uses it for a different reason.
But our beam port work became quite extensive.
mid-60s all the way up through early 70s.

And then it seemed like so much of this work was being done all over the world and in the national laboratories, mainly here in the United States, that it seemed like they reached a point where they figured they'd studied most of the major things.
And the interest in particle physics using a reactor kind of died away.
And it wasn't until a few years later that other uses were found for extracting beams.
Neutron radiography, for example, is a very popular common method now for use of a neutron beam to image an object by measuring the transmission of neutrons through that object.

and obtaining the image on the film, much like an x-ray would be done, except the nuclear particle you're dealing with is much different, and it interreacts with matter in a much different way than the x-ray would.
Research reactors of, say, our size, definitely are good tools for neutron radioactivity.
We have such a facility now.
These are good facilities for measuring defects in materials, metal castings, looking at plastic laminates that have been bonded by special glues or bonding agents.
And if the bonding agents contain moisture, then the bonding is probably going to fail.
So you can look at these materials and determine if you have a good bond.
And it's very, very good for looking at plastic explosives.
Small detonator devices like you would find in the ejector seats of military aircraft.
Also there's a lot of small explosives in the control systems of some aircraft.
They're computer controlled
And if you can't control the computer, if it goes completely on the whack, well, sometimes they will release control by explosive methods.
Just release the control wire by a small explosion.
We do that type of work.
We do some of that for NASA and their missile program.
And then Bell Helicopter, looking at some of the blades.
Not the final product, but the laboratory development research area in their blade work.
Because they're trying to make helicopter blades as light as they possibly can.
The plastics offer a much lighter blade.
And as I understand, an actually stronger blade.
When you can put it together by gluing it in a series of layers.
Put it together.
So the beam port work, we had involvement of the nuclear physicist, the nuclear engineer.
They're the types that would be looking at particle reactions.
These were all titled either something like Resonance Fluorescence Studies, which is excitation of energy levels in materials.
and neutron diffraction.
These were all kind of carryovers of what was going on in the national laboratories.
When all this nuclear business began, particularly for peaceful uses, we needed to know quite a bit of information about our isotopes.
What are their half-lives?
What are the gamma ray energies that come off of these materials?
once they're made radioactive?
How many identifiable isotopes do you have for each element?
How do they naturally occur in nature?
And so forth and so on.
So there's quite a bit of work being done in the 40s and 50s in the development of what we call the chart of the nuclei.
Texas A&M was not heavily involved in that.
But it led to the type of people that came to A&M.
You would find professors that were working in these labs, the national laboratories, that would come to A&M to join the staff, the faculty.
And in fact, there's still some of those individuals here.
Dr. John McIntyre works with cyclotron.
He was an extensive researcher here in particle physics studies.
using our beam ports.
And he had nuclear engineering students studying under him, physics students.
Quite interesting.
He's now with Cyclotron.
What is their connection at all between Cyclotron and the university?
There's no administrative connection, nor is there a connection as far as changing their customers or users, say.
They're completely different machines used for different purposes.
Now you can, you will probably find a researcher that may be interested in using both.
That happens.
His experiment may be such that he can do particular things at each place and that may be a possible requirement.
Yeah, we use the fission process, which is of course the first development.
Fusion development, we do not become involved in fusion because it's right now experimental.
It's in the development stage.
But the large power reactors,
hopefully one day will be fusion.
If you have a cleaner system with byproducts, the problems there go way down with fusion.
We have an infinite supply of energy.
That's the source for fusion.
It's infinite.
The heavy waters, the hydrogen, there's plenty of that.
It would be nice to achieve fusion, but the problem with it is the temperatures are so high in the reactive process that there's nothing man-made that will hold those temperatures.
So you have to do it in a very sophisticated electromagnetic field.
And the magnetic fields are very difficult to shape just perfectly.
to hold what we call the plasma.
And it breaks down, and it doesn't last very long.
That's the achievements of, of course, producing fusion.
We know that because we've seen fusion in our weapons.
But the peaceful use of it, developing it like we were able to get into the peaceful uses of our reactors using fission,
It's a much more difficult problem.
It's going to take many years to get there.
Does A&M plan on getting involved in the development?
A&M has had some involvement.
It's been on a small scale, either in the individual interest in the physics department in that area or individual interest, say, in the nuclear engineering aspect of it.
as well as the electrical engineer.
He enters into this picture too.
Most of it is being, I'd say, developed by the physicist.
Once the physicist has his theories all laid out and then he needs the engineer to come in and put it, have him put it together and get something that's functional.
That's where they are now.
They're, the two groups are working together, or the two disciplines are working together
hopefully achieve a continuous fusion reaction and produce energy.
From what I understand, I want to make a statement.
You tell me if I'm right or wrong.
The nuclear reactivant here is used more as a tool for the study of the effects or a tool in the study of something else using radiation.
rather than doing nuclear science research?
We do two things.
The majority of our work is we produce radioactive materials.
We take a material that is not radioactive and we introduce it to the reactor, to the neutrons that are present, and then we then have a radioactive material.
And you sell it?
We don't sell it.
We're just providing it to the experimenter.
We're a service facility.
No, we're not out saying that we've got all these materials on the shelf and you can buy them.
It's not that at all.
We are here to serve the experimenter.
And he will contact us.
And in many cases, he has an idea.
That's all it is.
He isn't familiar with working with radiation.
But in reading material, he's questioned if he could do a certain project
using a radioactive material, maybe a tracer.
Quite simply, describing a tracer would be the work being done in the animal science area by Dr. Ellis, where he's studying the digestive tract and also other things related to that in cattle.
He extracts samples from the animal's stomach
or multiple stomachs as they have.
And he will actually be tracing a material as it passes through the digestive tract of the animal.
And he will determine the use of that material by the animal in its nutritional uptake.
And he's doing that by not feeding the animal anything that's radioactive.
But he's putting a material in there that the reactor will make radioactive very easily and easily identifiable.
He puts a rare earth in there that is not commonly occurring.
It's something foreign to the animal.
You wouldn't see it in any other animal except the one that he's given that special feed to.
And then as he extracts the samples, we activate.
that material in the reactor.
He then will count the sample and he can identify the uptake or how much is being moved through the animal.
That's called the tracer method.
Another common tracer radioactive-wise is the medical application.
Tracing of iodine to the thyroid for a scan.
It's gotten to the point now where almost any of us that go to a doctor, we're gonna become involved with some radioactivity.
Either x-ray or they're gonna do a scan maybe.
Study the digestive tract.
The heart, they can take brain scans, thyroid scans.
Technetium is a very good isotope.
for human diagnostic work.
We make technetium here for the medical applications.
So the reason all this works is this material that is not radioactive, you place it in the reactor, it comes out of the reactor radioactive, but chemically it's still going to behave the same.
You put table salt, for example, in the reactor,
you're going to get out radioactive sodium and radioactive chlorine.
But it's still going to react with sodium chloride in any chemical reaction you want to involve it in.
And there's where the scientist can really use his imagination and put that to some use.
So most of what you produce is used...
In research.
A&M research and such?
These materials are used in research not only at A&M but in the medical fields and in industrial research.
We're not necessarily serving the industrial side where they're selling a product.
90% or more of what we do for our commercial or industrial people is research.
Materials are processes that will
be the benefit of mankind.
If you get a better product in the end, that's what we're after in serving these people.
You said there were two basic things you did.
Okay, that's the function of the reactor where you produce radioactivity in materials.
That's called activation.
If you're going to produce a given material, then that would be called isotope production of the other reactor.
The other use of the reactor is the extraction of the radiation that it gives off.
You're not necessarily producing the radioactive material anymore.
You're tailoring a particular series of radiation particles that come off the reactor.
In the nuclear reactor,
provides you with a complete span of energies, of neutrons and gamma rays.
It's called the spectra.
And the experimenter, in many cases, will place materials in the beam ports.
And he will block out certain energies of radiation particles he doesn't want.
Or he'll put something in there that scatters them away.
And he's left with the energy and the particle of interest.
That's quite clever and requires sometimes a lot of hard work to get that done, but it can be done.
Because the nuclear reactor, the fission process, gives you this wide range of energies to work with.
Whereas the accelerator,

will give you what we call the mono energetic energy the single energy and based upon the target that you choose for the high velocity for the accelerated particles it gets its name as an accelerator because it's taking charged particles charged nuclei and increasing their speeds to very high velocities bringing them up to those high speeds and then letting those
high-speed particles strike a target.
And in the reaction in that target, you will get a secondary radiation particle coming out that the experimenter uses.
But in most cases, that secondary that comes out of there from the particle being striking is usually a one energy.
It doesn't have this broad...
energy range of particles that we produce.
Most, almost all of our experimenters, though, are interested in the thermal, what we call the low energy neutron.
So when you think about research reactors, you always think of neutrons as being the primary radioactivity or radioactive particle.
or inducement of radioactivity that you deal with.
Now, we have gamma rays.
We can expose large systems or small samples all the way up to atoms that are 3, 4 feet across and 4, 5 feet high.
We can expose those to gamma rays and neutrons, and we can actually mix the two.
We have a large exposure for that kind of work.
Has the neutron probably once been true ever since the center's been in existence?
Oh, yes, because that's the main product of the reactor, sure.
Yeah, that would be the interest of the engineer and the scientist to ever build it in the first place, is to have something such as a nuclear reactor that will produce neutrons.
And once you have the neutrons, you can then start producing radioactive materials.
You had those two different functions of the nuclear reactor, and you had the exposure area.
Isotope production.
